section.title: Discourse markers
section.sectiontitle: Discourse markers help us to organise speech and writing. They show the relationship between different parts of what we say or write. There are many discourse markers with many functions. They can be used to soften an opinion.
section.text1: You were unfriendly to those people.
section.text1a: You were kind of unfriendly to those people.
section.sectiontitle2: Discourse markers can be used to make additional (contrasting) points.
section.text3: I think John finished the cake.
section.text3a: As a matter of fact, it was me who finished the cake.
section.text4: You look great in those clothes.

section.title: Discourse markers
section.sectiontitle: Discourse markers can be used to return to the main point.
section.text1: I haven't seen John for months.
section.text1a: Neither have I. Anyway, I think we should go to his party.
section.text2: I wish I was doing a Master's, like you.
section.text2a: Yes, it's great. At any rate, it's going to be useful in future.
section.sectiontitle2: Discourse markers can be used to change the subject.
section.text3a: I love this salmon. By the way, I saw your friend Maggie yesterday.
section.text4a: I spent the weekend in Paris. Incidentally, what's your new teacher like?

section.title: Discourse markers
section.sectiontitle: Discourse markers can be used to focus on the main topic.
section.text1a: As far as the food is concerned, this is the best restaurant in Madrid.
section.text2a: Regarding finances, we need to get sponsorship this year.
section.sectiontitle2: Discourse markers can be used to make a contrast with what came before.
section.text4: That film didn't make much money.
section.text4a: On the other hand, it won lots of awards.

section.title: Discourse markers
section.sectiontitle: Discourse markers can be used to introduce a personal opinion, often a criticism.
section.text1a: To be honest, I don't think you're right for this job.
